Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enhanced Circular Dichroism Sensing of Biomolecules Using Nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1403947/1403226
PI: Balaz, Milan/Dzyuba, Sergei
Collaborative Research: Enhanced Circular Dichroism Sensing of Biomolecules Using Nanoparticles

Technical terms: The proposed project aims to utilize achiral metallic or semiconductor nanoparticles (NPs) to enhance and modulate circular dichroism (CD) signal of chiral biomolecules. CD is the preferred technique for detection and analysis of chiral compounds and their interactions. Significant enhancement of the sensitivity of CD spectroscopy coupled with the ability to shift CD signals to longer wavelengths will allow examining structures of biological molecules as well as supramolecular biorecognition phenomena at biologically relevant concentrations with minimal amount of unwanted overlaps. The enhanced sensitivity and modularity is anticipated to rise from the electronic coupling between achiral NPs and chiral molecules in their proximity. We will prepare achiral NPs functionalized with chiral molecules and study their structure and experimental CD characteristics. We will perform theoretical simulations of CD spectra to gain detailed structural and mechanistic insights into the origins of induced CD in metallic and semiconductor NPs capped with chiral biomolecules. This is the first time that the achiral metallic and semiconductor NPs will be designed and optimized to specifically enhance CD of chiral molecules. The project will further enhance our understanding of the origin of induced chiroptical activity in achiral metallic and semiconductor NPs and will have an immediate impact on the fields of biosensing and chiroptical nanomaterials.

Layman terms: Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy allows to detect chiral biomolecules and study their interactions. The project will develop novel methods that enhance the sensitivity and resolution of CD detection by utilizing metallic or semiconductor particles of nanometer size as potent amplifiers of CD signal. Enhanced signal detection will be strongly beneficial for the detection and study of low concentration and complex mixture of biologically active molecules that are difficult to explore by current methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecules have well defined structures and shapes that determine their properties. Many molecules, including most biological molecules (e.g. amino acids or sugars) also possess an important geometric property, called chirality. Chiral molecules have a ‘handedness’, thus these molecules and their mirror images are not identical. This can be visualized by the left and right hands that are non-superimposable mirror images of each other. In nature, chirality has immense importance in molecular recognition and interaction (i.e. a molecule with the wrong chirality will not be able to interact with its intended biological target, just as the left hand will not fit into a right handed glove).

A common method of detecting the chirality (‘handedness’) of molecules is by circular dichroism spectroscopy, where the chiral molecules have a preferential absorption for left- and right-handed light. A main objective of this project was to explore how to utilize nanoparticles (nanometer sized particles, analogous to a ball) to improve the detection of chiral biomolecules. Nanoparticles made of semiconductor materials, also called quantum dots, were coated with chiral molecules (e.g. amino acids) on their surface. These coating molecules imprinted their chirality (‘handedness’) onto the nanoparticles, and the spectroscopic signal was not only amplified but also shifted to a more easily detectable wavelength, from the UV to the visible region. We have developed novel techniques for the synthesis of coated quantum dots, and we have utilized both experimental and computational techniques to propose a new, now widely accepted theory to explain how the surface coating molecules induced chirality (‘handedness’) onto the nanoparticles. We have shown that a combination of experimental and theoretical approaches could lead to the rational design of chiral nanomaterials, and the results impact the fields of biosensing, nanotechnology, chiroptical spectroscopy and supramolecular chemistry.

The PI's and co-PI's laboratories have provided great opportunities for underrepresented groups of students to participate in scientific research at the University of Wyoming and the University of New Hampshire. Both institutions are public universities that serve students from a wide range of backgrounds, many of whom come from rural areas. Graduate and undergraduate students in the PI's and co-PI's groups received valuable training that prepares them for their future careers in science.
